articles.headline: Sheila Michaels, Who Brought ‘Ms.’ to Prominence, Dies at 78
articles.snippet: Dissatisfied with other honorifics for women, Ms. Michaels undertook “a timid eight-year crusade” to usher the term back into being after decades of disuse.
articles.abstract: Dissatisfied with other honorifics for women, Ms. Michaels undertook “a timid eight-year crusade” to usher the term back into being after decades of disuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sheila Michaels, who half a century ago, wielding two consonants and a period, changed the way modern women are addressed, died on June 22 in Manhattan. Ms. Michaels, who introduced the honorific “Ms.” into common parlance, was 78.

articles.headline: Tiny Satellites From Silicon Valley May Help Track North Korea Missiles
articles.snippet: Civilian satellites developed to count cars in Target parking lots and monitor crops are being reconfigured to help the American military detect North Korea’s missile launches.
articles.abstract: Civilian satellites developed to count cars in Target parking lots and monitor crops are being reconfigured to help the American military detect North Korea’s missile launches.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years before North Korea fired its first intercontinental ballistic missile this week, the Pentagon and intelligence experts had sounded a warning: Not only was the North making progress quickly, spy satellite coverage was so spotty that the United States might not see a missile being prepared for launch.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Illinois Lawmakers Override Budget Veto, Ending Two-Year Stalemate
articles.snippet: While lawmakers and officials cheered an end to the longest state budget impasse in the nation’s history, a prominent critic remained — the governor.
articles.abstract: While lawmakers and officials cheered an end to the longest state budget impasse in the nation’s history, a prominent critic remained — the governor.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — After more than two years of political sparring, missed payments to creditors and plunging credit ratings, Illinois did on Thursday what most states do every year. It finished a budget.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Monica Davey

articles.headline: As Elites Switch to Texting, Watchdogs Fear Loss of Transparency
articles.snippet: Lawmakers, executives and other leaders are turning to encrypted chat apps to keep their communications under wraps, causing problems in industries where careful record-keeping is standard procedure.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers, executives and other leaders are turning to encrypted chat apps to keep their communications under wraps, causing problems in industries where careful record-keeping is standard procedure.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a bygone analog era, lawmakers and corporate chiefs traveled great distances to swap secrets, to the smoke-filled back rooms of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, or the watering holes at the annual Allen & Company conference in Sun Valley, Idaho.

articles.headline: Lasting Damage and a Search for Clues in Cyberattack
articles.snippet: An attack that started in Ukraine and spread throughout the world is still causing headaches for a number of big companies.
articles.abstract: An attack that started in Ukraine and spread throughout the world is still causing headaches for a number of big companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: As investigators continue to gather clues about the cyberattacks that hit computers around the world last week, some big companies and other organizations are still reckoning with the damage.

articles.headline: U.S. Job Growth Picks Up the Pace, but Wages Lag Behind
articles.snippet: Employers added 222,000 workers in June, a healthy showing, but a tightening labor market has not followed historical patterns in driving up pay.
articles.abstract: Employers added 222,000 workers in June, a healthy showing, but a tightening labor market has not followed historical patterns in driving up pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Automobile sales may be slowing, e-commerce is putting the squeeze on bricks-and-mortar stores, and overall economic growth is limp. But the labor market has nevertheless managed to charge ahead.

articles.headline: How a Home Bargain Became a ‘Pain in the Butt,’ and Worse
articles.snippet: A contract for deed, a seller-financed deal, can make it difficult to determine who owns a property, and who is responsible for paying taxes.
articles.abstract: A contract for deed, a seller-financed deal, can make it difficult to determine who owns a property, and who is responsible for paying taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: James R. Williams thought he had found a great deal on a home. The monthly fee on the three-story fixer-upper in Cincinnati was cheaper than the rent on his last home. And the payments would go toward the $40,000 he needed to own the place.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: One Woman’s Slide From Middle Class to Medicaid
articles.snippet: As the Senate prepares to once again take up its health care deliberations, Medicaid is on the chopping block. Will it be able to pay for your care someday?
articles.abstract: As the Senate prepares to once again take up its health care deliberations, Medicaid is on the chopping block. Will it be able to pay for your care someday?
articles.lead_paragraph: DEDHAM, Mass. — A dozen or so years into retirement, Rita Sherman had plenty going for her financially.

articles.headline: Berkshire Hathaway Makes a $9 Billion Bid for Energy Future Holdings
articles.snippet: The deal would augment Berkshire Hathaway Energy, whose collection of utilities delivers power to 11.6 million customers across the West and Midwest.
articles.abstract: The deal would augment Berkshire Hathaway Energy, whose collection of utilities delivers power to 11.6 million customers across the West and Midwest.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fate of a giant Texas power company that has spent nearly a decade in financial distress lies in a potential battle between two billionaires.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
